image.altText: Ecologist Dana Bergstrom kneels among rocks by the sea

items.synopsis: A prominent ecologist tells senators it's "too hard to do science" at the Australian Antarctic Division, revealing she quit due to advice from her dentist.

title.children: Stressed former Antarctic researcher had 'four cracked molars', quit on advice from her dentist

image.altText: Tasmania Police shoulder patch

items.synopsis: Commissioner Donna Adams says a review will assess the actions of Paul Reynolds and whether there had been any misconduct by police officers involved in the investigation.

title.children: Tasmania's Police Commissioner announces police handling of child sex abuse allegations is being reviewed

image.altText: Donald Trump standing next to Anthony Pratt.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump is accused of discussing "potentially sensitive" details of America’s nuclear submarine program with Australian billionaire Anthony Pratt.

title.children: 'Criminal leaking': Trump hits back after former president accused of sharing sensitive details

image.altText: A photograph of a computer screen displaying a broken web link.

items.synopsis: Home Affairs and Immigration webpages have been targeted by a denial-of-service attack that has prevented people from lodging visa or citizenship applications.

title.children: Home Affairs and Immigration sites hit by denial-of-service cyber attacks

image.altText: The wreckage of a plane can be seen on the burnt ground in a field.

items.synopsis: Emergency services are at the scene of a fatal light aircraft crash at Gundaroo, after it took off from Canberra Airport about 2:30pm. Police say they are still confirming how many people were on board.

title.children: Fatal light aircraft crash north of Canberra, number of casualties yet to be confirmed

image.altText: Anthony Albanese stands opposite a man.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Aboriginal leader says Voice proposal 'ill-conceived', as Albanese tells voters 'No will leave us nowhere'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by James Mcmanagan Speaking on a special Hobart broadcast of The Drum, chairman of the Aboriginal Land Council of Tasmania Michael Mansell says he believes the referendum was "ill-conceived" by the Albanese government. “The method of using the constitution instead of legislation was never thought through properly," Mr Mansell said. "The whole [Yes] campaign has been inflexible. “The moment [the Yes campaign] got to April this year and realised that there was not going to a bipartisanship, they should have taken stock and gone back to Albanese and said, 'No referendum has ever passed without bipartisanship.' "They wanted to crash, or crash through. "Both sides have exaggerated their position. The Yes campaign are trying to convince the country that the prime minister, state premiers and peak organisations cannot reduce and close the gap, but an advisory body that meets a few times a year in Canberra is going to be able to do it." The Drum Hobart special broadcast airs at 6pm AEDT
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Michael Mansell says Yes campaign has been 'inflexible'

children.content: Michael Mansell.
(ABC News)
Reporting by
James Mcmanagan
Speaking on a special Hobart broadcast of The Drum, chairman of the Aboriginal Land Council of Tasmania
Michael Mansell
says he believes the referendum was "ill-conceived" by the Albanese government.
“The method of using the constitution instead of legislation was never thought through properly," Mr Mansell said.
"The whole [Yes] campaign has been inflexible.

“The moment [the Yes campaign] got to April this year and realised that there was not going to a bipartisanship, they should have taken stock and gone back to Albanese and said, 'No referendum has ever passed without bipartisanship.'
"They wanted to crash, or crash through.

"Both sides have exaggerated their position. The Yes campaign are trying to convince the country that the prime minister, state premiers and peak organisations cannot reduce and close the gap, but an advisory body that meets a few times a year in Canberra is going to be able to do it."
The Drum Hobart special broadcast airs at 6pm AEDT

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Myles Houlbrook-Walk Anthony Albanese has visited one of the biggest mosques in Australia speaking to muslims at Friday prayers about The Voice to Parliament. In his pitch, he spoke of the longstanding relationship between Muslims and First Australians — forged between Yolŋu from North East Arnhem Land and traders from Makassar — before European colonisation. Mr Albanese asked the hundreds at the Lakemba Mosque for regular Friday prayers to "appeal to our better angles". "This referendum won't be decided by politicians, it will be decided by everyone in this room above 18," he said. Mr Albanese also claimed that regardless of progressive or conservative arguments for the No vote, it would leave the country stuck in addressing disadvantage. "There is no progressive Yes or progressive No," he said. "Voting No leaves us nowhere. No recognition. No way forward." Alongside the PM, president of the Australian National Imams Council, Sheikh Shady Alsuleiman, called on fellow Muslims to vote Yes. "We are committed to the Voice and we will say Yes to the Voice," he said. "Inshallah, on October 15 we will wake up and every single Australian will see the success of the Voice." The Labor Party is working hard to grow the Yes vote among multicultural and diverse communities. Yesterday Indigenous Affairs Minister Linda Burney addressed a group of about 100 older Chinese Australians, with her speech translated into Mandarin and Cantonese.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Albanese says 'voting No will leave us nowhere'

children.content: Prime Minister at Lakemba Mosque today.
(ABC News: Myles Houlbrook-Walk)
Reporting by Myles Houlbrook-Walk
Anthony Albanese has visited one of the biggest mosques in Australia speaking to muslims at Friday prayers about The Voice to Parliament.

In his pitch, he spoke of the longstanding relationship between Muslims and First Australians — forged between Yolŋu from North East Arnhem Land and traders from Makassar — before European colonisation.
Mr Albanese asked the hundreds at the Lakemba Mosque for regular Friday prayers to "appeal to our better angles".
"This referendum won't be decided by politicians, it will be decided by everyone in this room above 18," he said.
(ABC News: Myles Houlbrook-Walk)
Mr Albanese also claimed that regardless of progressive or conservative arguments for the No vote, it would leave the country stuck in addressing disadvantage.
"There is no progressive Yes or progressive No," he said.
"Voting No leaves us nowhere. No recognition. No way forward."
Alongside the PM, president of the Australian National Imams Council, Sheikh Shady Alsuleiman, called on fellow Muslims to vote Yes.
"We are committed to the Voice and we will say Yes to the Voice," he said.
"Inshallah, on October 15 we will wake up and every single Australian will see the success of the Voice."
(ABC News: Myles Houlbrook-Walk)
The Labor Party is working hard to grow the Yes vote among multicultural and diverse communities.
Yesterday Indigenous Affairs Minister Linda Burney addressed a group of about 100 older Chinese Australians, with her speech translated into Mandarin and Cantonese.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The government says the Voice is designed to improve Indigenous lives and Close the Gap. Carly Williams says while some Close the Gap targets are on track others are going backwards. "What we are seeing worsening is early childhood development, adults in prison, children in out-of-home care and Indigenous suicide rates," she said. "We don'thave a crystal ball to know if the Voice is going to magically fix this, especially how fast that can happen." Fran Kelly says the argument put forward by those supporting the Voice is that is will be hearing from grassroots communities that will be coming up with ideas on what would work. Williams says that history shows that when mob are part of the decision-making process it results in the most fruitful outcomes. "This is aboutself-determination, that is what the government and Yes advocates say," she says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How can a Voice improve Indigenous lives?

children.content: The government says the Voice is designed to improve Indigenous lives and Close the Gap.
Carly Williams says while some Close the Gap targets are on track others are going backwards.
"What we are seeing worsening is early childhood development,
adults in prison, children in out-of-home care and Indigenous suicide rates," she said.
"We don'thave a crystal ball to know if the Voice is going to magically fix this, especially how fast that can happen."
Fran Kelly says the argument put forward by those supporting the Voice is that is will be hearing from grassroots communities that will be coming up with ideas on what would work.
Williams says that history shows that when mob are part of the decision-making process it results in the most fruitful outcomes.
"This is aboutself-determination, that is what the government and Yes advocates say," she says.

image.altText: A young man in a Hudsons Coffee uniform gives a thumbs up while leaning against a cafe counter.

items.synopsis: More businesses are recognising the benefits of employing people with disability, but "misconceptions and stereotypes" remain, a support agency says.

title.children: More businesses are becoming inclusive for people with disability, and Finn works for one of them

image.altText: A young woman looking at the camera, holding arms.

items.synopsis: With one of the most common yet stigmatised mental illnesses, people with borderline personality disorder often feel they are turned away by emergency first responders despite their high suicidal risks. Now experts and advocates want a change on this.

title.children: People with borderline personality disorders call for more compassion and understanding from first responders

image.altText: An aerial view of a new suburb with townhouses and apartments.

items.synopsis: A rising number of households in financial stress, but the RBA says it won't threaten our banking system

title.children: A rising number of households on the cusp of financial stress, says Reserve Bank

image.altText: A man of East Asian background wearing medical scrubs. He is a wheelchair user

items.synopsis: Dr Dinesh Palipana says a ground crew member at Brisbane Airport ignored his carers and manoeuvred his wheelchair sharply, tipping him onto the ground.

title.children: Doctor with quadriplegia who was 'tipped' out of his wheelchair says airline staff ignored his concerns

image.altText: Director Nash Edgerton and Briggs on set for their skit at a pub.

items.synopsis: It starts with a conversation you might have had with a friend or family member over the last few months.

title.children: 'Just Google it': The Voice message that cut through and the Australian rapper that reached millions

image.altText: A family of children adults and older people sit in a line, looking out of frame as the sun shines on them.

items.synopsis: Migrant families are putting their lives on hold as they wait years and even decades to hear if their parents will be able to settle in Australia.

title.children: Migrants are watching their parents grow old, give up and even die waiting for visas that may never come

image.altText: A farmer in a blue shirt and jeans inspects a flooded paddock.

items.synopsis: Temporary supply shortages of vegetables and fruit are on the cards as individual farmers see many millions of dollars of produce and infrastructure wash away in Victoria's east.

title.children: Men rescued from floodwaters, damage bill in the millions, as Victorian flood clean-up begins

image.altText: A row boat sinking in the ocean with a man clinging on

items.synopsis: The 24-year-old's distress beacon was activated about 5pm on Thursday after the boat was damaged.

title.children: Cruise ship detours 200 kilometres to rescue Brisbane man clinging to row boat

image.altText: A doctor in a lab coat, face unseen, makes notes on a form attached to a clipboard.

items.synopsis: The South Australian registrar forged more than 40 prescriptions over the course of more than a year, breaching the trust of his colleagues and jeopardising public faith in the healthcare system.

title.children: GP sentenced for forging opioid prescriptions for personal use

image.altText: A blank Voice to Parliament ballot paper

items.synopsis: Dozens of constitutional and public law teachers from across the country have signed a letter in a bid to tackle "misunderstandings and misconceptions" about the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Voice 'is not constitutionally risky', say 71 law professors in open letter to Australian public

image.altText: A male lion stalks through grassland, with its mouth open and one of its front paws raised slightly.

items.synopsis: Lions have long been seen as one of the world's most fearsome predators, but according to a new study, wildlife's fear of humans surpasses that of the big cats.

title.children: 'Super predator': New study shows animals fear humans more than lions

image.altText: A jogger runs along the shore of Manly Beach after sunrise on the first day of Spring in Sydney, 2008

items.synopsis: The world is very warm right now. We're not only seeing record temperatures, but the records are being broken by record-wide margins, writes Andrew King.

title.children: Six reasons why global temperatures are spiking right now

image.altText: An image of footprints scattered on a sandy surface.

items.synopsis: New research confirms that fossil human footprints in New Mexico are likely the oldest direct evidence of human presence in the Americas, a finding that up-ends what many archaeologists thought they knew about when our ancestors arrived in the New World.

title.children: Further evidence points to human footprints found in US National Park being up to 23,000 years old

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in a historic building.

items.synopsis: Analysis of more than 3,000 bank branches nationally suggests hundreds of regional locations are at risk of being closed, in addition to more than 1,600 closed around the country in the past six years.

title.children: Hundreds of bank branches are 'at risk' of shutting around the country. Here's where they're located

image.altText: A scientific image of five green COVID-19 viruses floating

items.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 news and case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction for the past week.

title.children: All the latest COVID-19 case numbers from around Australia

image.altText: Lloyd Rayne outside court

items.synopsis: A forensic investigator who was found to have defamed former Perth barrister Lloyd Rayney by suggesting he "murdered his wife and got away with it" fails in an appeal against the ruling.

title.children: Forensic investigator ordered to pay $350,000 for defaming Lloyd Rayney loses appeal

image.altText: An older man wearing a dark suit chews his nails as he suits at a small cafe table

items.synopsis: The manager of security for Corrective Services NSW tells an inquiry into Wayne Astill's offending that he didn't know why there was no footage but admitted the number of cameras was "inadequate".

title.children: 'Strange' no vision exists of guard's sexual abuse of inmates, despite 175 CCTV cameras in jail, inquiry told

image.altText: Kylie Minogue wearing a pink dress and heels poses laying back on an emerald green bed.

items.synopsis: Kylie Minogue has her highest US sales week for an album in almost 20 years, topping Billboard's Dance/Electronic Albums chart.

title.children: Viral hit Padam Padam returns Kylie Minogue to the top of US album charts

image.altText: An island

items.synopsis: The government has run out of patience, filing legal action over a derelict tropical island resort off Cairns once frequented by Hollywood actors Brad Pitt and Jennifer Aniston.

title.children: Once favoured by celebrities, Double Island is now a ruin and the Queensland government has had enough

image.altText: An elderly man standing beside a red car

items.synopsis: The trial of a New Zealand sex worker accused of murdering a NSW Central West man seven years ago wraps up, with defence lawyers arguing the prosecution failed to rule out the possibility he was killed by other people.

title.children: Trial of sex worker accused of murdering farmer hears 'associates' may be responsible for death

image.altText: A close up of a P plate on a car windscreen

items.synopsis: A court has heard there were plenty of warning signs Kane Mueller should not have driven. But he did, and caused a fatal crash that has left the victim's family emotionally devastated.

title.children: Drunk P-plater hit keep left sign, vomited at friend's house before causing fatal crash

image.altText: Francois Ghassibe walking handcuffed, with a face mask on

items.synopsis: An Adelaide judge finds Francois Joseph Ghassibe administered a "flurry of blows" to his victim, culminating with a single kick to the chin, but finds him not guilty of murdering the 70-year-old.

title.children: Man who inflicted 'flurry of blows' in Adelaide road rage fight found not guilty of murder

image.altText: the exterior of an office building with Australian Federal Police above the door

items.synopsis: A 19-year-old man is charged with child abuse offences after an international tip-off led police to raid his home.

title.children: Tip-off from US police leads to child abuse charges against Queensland man

image.altText: England batter Joe Root looks over his shoulder after playing a shot in the Cricket World Cup.

items.synopsis: The first match of the 50-over World Cup in cricket-mad India draws criticism for a small crowd, due at least in part to a lack of details around the tournament until shortly before it started.

title.children: Spot the spectator as New Zealand's win over England gets Cricket World Cup in India underway

image.altText: A woman on a boat looks back at a great white shark on the water, with a tuna in her lap

items.synopsis: Izzy Sesto's catch off the south-eastern coast of South Australia was a few kilos lighter after a great white shark took the bluefin tuna's tail then had a "play" with the boat's motors.

title.children: Fisher's 'epic' shark encounter as great white takes chunk out of massive tuna

image.altText: Male rescue workers working near the site of a badly damaged building.Trees in the background.

items.synopsis: Ukrainian officials say a Russian attack on a village in the north-east of the country has killed 51 people, including a child.

title.children: 'No military targets': Russian missile attack kills more than 50 civilians in one of the deadliest strikes in Ukraine war

image.altText: Marcus Stoinis poses for a photo in New York

items.synopsis: Australian all-rounder Marcus Stoinis reveals the moment he realised an impromptu photo shoot on the streets of New York was about to go viral.

title.children: 'Oh no. What have I done?': The impromptu NYC photo shoot that introduced an Aussie cricketer to a million new fans
